sen.j: 辻ヶ花（つじがはな）とは、室町時代から桃山時代にかけて現れた絞り染めの技法。
sen.e: "Tsujigahana" is a Japanese tie-dyeing technique, which was devised around from the Muromachi period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.e: Tsujigahana is a Japanese tie-dyeing technique, which was devised around from the Muromachi period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.j: 最盛期に当たる桃山～江戸時代初期にかけては、複雑な縫い締め絞り・竹皮絞りなどの高度な技法が使用された。
sen.e: When at its peak from Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period, tsujigahana developed complex and high-level techniques, such as "nuishime shibori" (the technique that makes patterns on cloth by tying some parts of it with strings before putting it in a dye) and "takekawa shibori" (the technique that makes patterns on cloth by tying some parts of it with strings and bamboo peels before putting it in a dye).

sen.j: これらにより多色染め分けによる高度な染物が創り出された。
sen.e: These techniques enabled dyeing in various colors, so elabolate dyed goods were created, which contributed - along with "surihaku" (a dyeing technique that uses foil applique) - to the luxurious and splendid culture in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

sen.e: In those days, tsujigahana was almost synonymous with the dyeing technique, they say.

sen.j: しかし、江戸中期に糊で防染する友禅の技法が出現・発展すると、自由度・手間の両面で劣る辻ヶ花は、急速に廃れ消滅した。
sen.e: However, when the technique "yuzen," which uses starch for preventing a dye from soaking into cloth, was devised and developed in the middle of the Edo period, tsujigahana rapidly went into decline and disappeared, because tsujigahana was inferior to yuzen in leeway and labor.

sen.j: 技法が急速度で廃れたことと、名の由来が定説を持たないことから、幻の染物と呼ばれる事も多い。
sen.e: Tsujigahana is often called a phantom dyeing technique, because it rapidly went into decline and because it has no established theory about its name origin.
